content:
Hi all. Recently, I've had the urge to expand the "suggested workflows" of the dev-guide and merge it into a cleaned-up CONTRIBUTING.md. I laid out these goals in the docs stream on discord

I've long wanted to make onboarding easier by giving a very detailed "walkthrough" for each of the ways of contributing in-tree that are listed in CONTRIBUTING.md. Specifically, I want to provide an exact series of ./x.py and git commands that will are needed to, for example, check out, modify and build the standard library documentation.
Do others think this would be desirable and (more importantly) worth the maintenance burden?
Specifically, there's some ./x.py workflows that AFAICT are not widely known and might alleviate common problems for newcomers (see https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/71458). Even just telling people what parts what things are going to be slow ahead of time (initial checkout, first build of LLVM if not using the system one) would make things less daunting for first-time contributors.
This also includes the "How to build and run the compiler" section I suppose.
I'm happy to do the legwork myself with feedback from both y'all and the docs team. cc @mark-i-m since this is somewhat related to a conversation we had about the first-time contributor survey
@ecstatic-morse this is great :heart:
I've seen this is from yesterday and I was just able to read it, also saw some comments on github and replied
Hey @Santiago Pastorino @ecstatic-morse , I just wanted to followup here: I opened https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/753

I think this is largely orthogonal to the ideas you mentioned above. Basically, now that the Getting Started guide is almost ready, I wanted to change the rust-lang/rust README and CONTRIBUTING.md to point to it primarily
But then I didn't want to get rid of the content, because I like @ecstatic-morse 's idea
So I opened that PR to move it as-is to the rustc-dev-guide until we can clean things up
And I took the opportunity to do a bit of reorganizing
Does this seem like a reasonable approach?
:+1: from me
